 | | | || ||

**Temperature ($^o$F)** |$85$ | $90$| $93$ | $95$ | $96$|$96.5$

hints.content:
A residual is the actual data value minus its predicted value.  The actual data are plotted below, along with the model.  Some of the residual values are shown.  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/3923d94e20edfad7a4ebe85904c312bf39598742.png)

The residual plot looks like this:  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9f27654875636a40dd1c3838bf3c8a3f3802e613.png)

If a model is a good fit for a data set, the scatter plot of the residuals should not show any trend.  It should show a random set of points that are centered at zero.  

The residual plot here shows a linear trend. As the $x$-values increase, the residuals become increasingly positive.

Since the slope of the model is steeper than the slope of the data, we need to make the slope of the model shallower.   

And as $x$ approaches $0$, the residuals approach $0$.  Therefore, the $y$ - intercept does not need to be changed.

The following answers are correct:

- Make the slope of the line shallower.  
$r(0) = 0$  
$r(10)  = 0$  
$r(20)  = 10$  
$r(30) = 15$  
$r(40)  = 20$  
$r(50) = 30$  


![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/9f27654875636a40dd1c3838bf3c8a3f3802e613.png)

question.content:
Paul runs track, and he is training to improve his time in the $400$-meter race.  He does a time trial every $10$ days to monitor his improvement.  He's used the line $y = -1.5x + 120$ to model his $400$-meter time as a function of the number of days he has trained.   

**In the table below, calculate the residual value for each point.  Then plot the residuals on the graph below.**   

**Which of the following changes would improve the fit of the model?** 

[[☃ radio 1]]

 | | | || | |
- | - | -
**Number of days** |$0$ | $10$| $20$ | $30$ | $40$|$50$
**Time (seconds)** | $120$ | $105$| $100$ | $90$| $80$|$75$|  
**Residual value** | [[☃ input-number 1]] | [[☃ input-number 2]]|  [[☃ input-number 3]]| [[☃ input-number 4]]|[[☃ input-number 5]]|[[☃ input-number 6]]
  

[[☃ interactive-graph 1]]

choices.content: Make the slope of the line steeper.
Make the slope of the line shallower.
Increase the y-intercept of the line.
Decrease the y-intercept of the line.
None of the above - the model is a good fit for the data.

hints.content:
A residual is the actual data value minus its predicted value.  The actual data are plotted below, along with the model.  Some of the residual values are shown.  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b0b6b27b48eaa720e74897a2340fad19a2d973c2.png)

The residual plot looks like this:  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d820221bce8985f53ecbbb5559d15072c8c4e1d9.png)

If a model is a good fit for a data set, the scatter plot of the residuals should not show any trend.  It should show a random set of points that are centered at zero.  

The residual plot here shows a linear trend. As the $x$-values increase, the residuals become increasingly positive.

To improve the fit, we need to do two things.  First, since the slope of the actual data is steeper than the slope of the model, we need to *increase* the slope of the model.   

Once we increase the slope, the model will be roughly parallel to the actual data, but the data will all be below the line.  We also need to *decrease* the $y$-intercept.

The following answers are correct:

-  Increase the slope of the line. 
- Decrease the y-intercept of the line.  
$r(0)  = -16$  
$r(10)= -9$  
$r(20) = -4$  
$r(30) = 4$  
$r(40) = 8$  
$r(50) = 14$  


![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/d820221bce8985f53ecbbb5559d15072c8c4e1d9.png)

hints.content:
The graph below shows the actual data values.  The red lines extending from the data points show the residuals.  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/2347c66359dae1735cd545b332e19b51dfd53212.png)

To find the equation of a line, we need $2$ points.  We can use the table to find these points.  A residual equals the actual data value minus its predicted value.  Since we know the residuals and we know the actual data values,  we can figure out the predicted values, which are points on the line.

Let's figure out the $y$-value when $x=1$:  
$\text{residual value} = \text{actual data value} - \text{predicted value}$  
$-3 = 22-\text{predicted value}$  
So the predicted value is $25$ when $x=1$.  The point $(1, 25)$ is on the line.  

Let's figure out the $y$-value when $x=2$:  
$\text{residual value} = \text{actual data value} - \text{predicted value}$  
$-2 = 35-\text{predicted value}$  
So the predicted value is $37$ when $x=2$.  The point $(2, 37)$ is on the line.

Let's find the slope of the line that goes through the points $(1, 25)$ and $(2, 37)$.  
$\text{slope}= \dfrac{y2-y1}{x2-x1}= \dfrac{37-25}{2-1}=12$

Let's find the $y$ -intercept of a line that has a slope of $12$ and goes through the point $(1, 25)$.  
$25 = 12\times1 + b$  
$b = 13$  

So the equation of the model is $y = 12x + 13$.

The graph below shows the model with the data and the residuals.  
![](https://ka-perseus-graphie.s3.amazonaws.com/b09ae999c9c50373cee79f323a19c54f3ed37092.png)
The equation of the model is $y = 12x + 13$.
